comments.commentBody:
Suzy: There is an error in the story and photograph. The Princess of Wales is not wearing a tiara of Romanov provenance. She is wearing what is called the "Cambridge Lover's Knot Tiara," one that was commissioned in 1914 by Queen Mary who, in a nostalgic vein, wanted to recreate the lover's knot tiara that belonged to her grandmother, Princess Augusta of Hesse. Originally each knot was surmounted by an oval pearl to mirror each drop below but by 1935 it was simplified to its present form. Queen Mary passed it to her granddaughter Queen Elizabeth who in turn presented it to Diana upon the occasion of her marriage to Prince Charles.

You are confusing this with another tiara (the one with Russian provenance), which is known as the Grand Duchess Vladimir Tiara." That tiara (not pictured with this story) was commissioned by the Grand Duchess Vladimir of Russia in 1890, and consists of fifteen interlaced diamond circles each centered by a swinging teardrop pearl. After the Bolshevik Revolution the Grand Duchess and her jewels narrowly made it out of the country. When the Duchess died in 1920 the tiara passed to her daughter Helen who was by then Princess Nicholas of Greece. In 1921 Princess Nicholas sold the tiara to Queen Mary and it has been with the Windsors ever since, passing to Queen Elizabeth in 1953. It is a perennial favorite and the pearls can also be changed out with emerald drops (Queen Mary devised this with the remaining unmounted Cambridge emeralds, which you also referenced "wearing like a squaw" in the story).
Not digging the shoes.  Everything else is good.  Pure Prada!!!

They're just looking for an excuse to fire him without having to pay compensation.
Seems clear to me.
Watch it happen.

I'm not worried about Kate's headgear or her jewels. My concern is that she quit her day job. Check out this blog for an argument as to why she might want to reconsider that decision:

she sometimes came into the small deli at Bleeker and Morton street, with Joseph Brodsky, in fall 1978.  I'd make her a salad to go.  I loved the grey streak in her hair.  She was regal.

Well I guess this story's comments lead me to the following conclusions:

1. Rename the Dept. of Justice to Dept. of Wewillprosecutewhowewant.

2. It might be time to get rid of the jury system period.

3. Ageism is alive and thriving in this country
(what a disgrace that commenters without ever having spoken to Mr.Heicklen call him senile, demented and worse).

4. Kudos to all of the commenters who called out those posters.

5. Overzealous prosecution is rampant due to the fact that we have a million DA's, Asst DA's who have to demonstrate that they are sorely needed to protect us.

6. Justice (or what occasionally passes for it) in this country is BIG business.

7. Just try and change laws that keep the 'justice' gravy train running. If you start decriminalizing drugs then what do the agencies that employ thousands of drug 'crime' fighters do?

8. Two hundred and twenty years gone by since the Bill of Rights and the private citizen's ability to affect real change in government seems to decline with every passing year - how sad!!!!

It's too bad the 'conservatives' don't actually have the courage to shift spending from entitlements to investment (not just investment bankers). Instead, they are just pursuing partisan pet projects.

Health care reform could really shift spending from entitlements to investment and help workers to get raises in salary instead of insurance premiums. Too bad 'conservatives' are unwilling to participate in meaningful reform of the our health system so we could cut deficits and start investing in our future, not just 5 more days of suffering for our sickest citizens.

Government spending adds to GDP only if the spending is done with borrowed money, but if the government taxes me it's simply a transfer of money to the government who spends the money that I can no longer spend. It's essentially a wash. At some point point borrowing becomes unsustainable and hihg interest rates and debt service becomes a serious drag on the economy.
Patricia's, Pryan's and gwa's comments say it for me. "bearing witness" powerful. thank you brave photographers, nyt.

Proud moment, as well for Professor Komenich and a long tradition of committed photojournalism at San Jose State, where he earned his first degree, and where the contributing reporter, Joe Proudman, now a graduate student at Columbia University, also earned his first degree in photojournalism.

If a "jury of one's peers" is to have any core meaning, then Julian P. Heicklen should be considered a hero, not a villain. If a jury merely rubber stamps what judges and prosecutors say, it is not a jury but a sham that deceives the public into believing that trials are complete, comprehensive and fair. And just what are the prosecutors scared of, if they do their job and make their cases effectively?! On the contrary, they should welcome critical review by juries as an additional check on their own accuracy and the rights of the accused.

I think it is ethically problematic to make no distinction in financing adaptation responses between human induced climate harms and those harms that might have happened anyway because of the vulnerability of some to non-human climate variations. .To merge all harms into one category of climate vulnerability blurs important distinctions that retributive justice finds essential. It is true that it will be difficult for some climate change harms to separate harms that would have happened to people anyway and harms that are attributable to human action. However not all climate change harms are plagued by this problem. For instance, we have a pretty good idea how much glacier retreat and consequent reduction in surface water, sea level rise, and increases in vector borne disease are attributable to human causation. Justice would require those who are causing these harms shoulder some of the burden for the damages. For those problems which are more difficult to separate human and natural causation, rules of thumb based upon probability can be developed. This is actually done in tort litigation frequently. As far as other inevitable conflicts over adaptation monies are concerned, institutional fixes will be required which look at just procedures for making tough decisions.

Donald A. Brown, Professor Environmental Ethics, Science, and Law, Penn State University.

Of course, denial is always the easy way to avoid having to spend money and change how we live. Besides, it's too late. The level of obtuseness by deniers has already made significant climate change essentially unavoidable. Even when it is evident everywhere, the fools will continue to insist it can't be a result of human activity. They haven't read Jared Diamond's Collapse, so they don't understand what happens to those who live in denial. Unfortunately, they take the rest of us with them.

Eclectic Pragmatist — http://eclectic-pragmatist.tumblr.com/

What about places that are already climatelly dangerous?

For instance, should billions of dollars in climate change funds be available for residents of Florida if hurricanes hit them more often due to global warming?

Would it be fair? Is not like people who move to Florida are ignorant of hurricane disasters such as 1919/800 dead, 1926/800 dead, 1928/1000 dead, 1935/408 dead.

Along the same lines, why should _any_ climate change money go to the Sahara or West Africa (droughts), Bangladesh (floods), South Asia shores (Monsoon), Latin America (mudslides), etc? People who have built their homes in solid, safe ground, even poor people, will rightfully say... why are you spending money on people who built their homes in sand?

Ever heard of the Three Pigs and the Wolf story? All in all, this billions-in-taxpayer funds seems rather harebrained.

Dear Aliens:

I could be speaking gibberish right now and you probably wouldn't even know. I could be speaking in any language known to mankind right now, be it Chinese, Spanish, or English, and you would probably just stare at me absolutely confused (Well, of course, this is under the assumption that you even have eyes). I honestly don't think there's anything for me to say to you, because chances are, you're going to be speaking gibberish right back or maybe, making strange motions that leave us confused or ready to fire some bullets at you (purely self-defense, of course). Guess what results from this exchange? Gibberish... on both ends.

Orson:

"would climategate have generated an attempt at a transparent temperature data base like BEST - Berkeley Earth Surface Temperature project - unlike the government funded ones in question? Of course not."

All the GHCN data is available online, and if you'd like to work with the *really* raw data, you can ask for DVDs of electronic scans of the original paper forms filed by observers around the world.

The NASA GISTemp code is online and freely available.

Many people, including a fair number from the denialist camp, have written their own temp reconstruction software using GHCN data ...

And all come up with trends that match each other very closely.

What is lacking in transparency?

Yes, CRU couldn't release records for a few countries, but that could be easily solved - ASK THOSE COUNTRIES FOR THEIR DATA. If they insist on charging for it, pass the hat and pay for it. CRU isn't responsible for the fact that Sweden, for instance, treated their data as proprietary for years. Neither is NOAA. The Swedish government was.

Etc etc.

i believe even lester brown is starting to distance himself from the sinking ship of climate activism. he appeared on the brian lehrer npr talk show in nyc this morning, and although he later dutifully bowed to climate change as one of the contributants on the 'supply' side of environmental degradation, the takeaway message, delivered right at the start of the interview, was that most the environmental degradation threats the world faces existed before -- and even without any consideration of -- anthropogenic climate change.

and he is quite right: the world faces grave environmental threats, mostly from exploding population amidst finite resources, many of which -- especially oil and water -- may have already peaked. threats that will continue to exist and impinge on humanity, with or without climate change. his first statement (paraphrase) on the interview, was "there are no longer any reliable local norms on which to predictably base our expectations or fears or desires of either ideal climate or of climate change."

it's my understanding that, beyond the vaguest 'pledge' -- similar to the usual anodyne, lip service pledges to try to end war and poverty all over the world -- no country has signed any agreement whatsoever to pay a dime to any 'climate affected' country. not ever.

no? show me.
Okay, so the ice floe montage with Senator Inhofe was in 'poor taste'. What kind of taste is building an igloo on the mall and calling it 'Al Gore's New Home'?

So RayPierre, if adding all that potential CO2 warming is committing us, then just what does all that potential warming from water do? Are you now saying that we shoulf get rid of the oceans?

One other thing,. my pet rock absorbs energy (gets hot) in the morning & delays the release of the heat until mid afternoon. Just exactly like CO2 absorbs an energy photon & delays the release for a few microseconds. Funny thing, ALL matter does this. So are you now saying we should eliminate all matter?

The common element is all these is that it is required that more energy photons are required to get more warming (via the Greenhouse effect). If the sun doesn't heat up to provide the energy (& fry us in the process) then none of the other warming will happen either. This whole thing is a big fraud.

Please ignore the comments that insist on returning to denial. Please read the article and stick to the topic.

Real skeptics look at all the data. As is characteristic of this comment section, it appears these advocates have given themselves a free pass, don't believe anything from top course, and don't want you to think for yourself.

Don't worry about this too much:  every nation that might contribute is either too poor (Europe) or too smart (China, Canada, the US) to give the UN anything in the name of the scam.  So the Third World delegates can all promise themselves 100 percent of the pot, or 1000 percent for that matter.

This is the key, the fact that population growth is barely mentioned:
> Will you see climate adaptation money spent on family planning? Given that population has barely been mentioned in climate negotiations. I wouldn’t bet on it, even though the logic is there.

It's not about "us" telling "them" what to do, it's about empowering women, American women and all women in the world, to truly be able to choose family size.

Lately it does seem that American women have to fight to keep the reproductive rights we have here, nevermind exporting choice elsewhere.

I would include men in the empowering part as well .. except, wait, they already are in power.
